title: 112_s1185
content: The Act titled "Ethanol Reform and Deficit Reduction Act" establishes a variable VEETC rate based on the price of crude oil. The excise tax credit is amended to include different rates for calendar quarters before and after July 1, 2011. "The Act establishes a variable VEETC rate based on the price of crude oil." The variable VEETC rate is based on the average price of crude oil for each calendar quarter, with different rates depending on the price range. The rates range from 30 cents per barrel for prices not exceeding $50/barrel to 0 cents per barrel for prices exceeding $90/barrel. The VEETC rate is adjusted quarterly based on crude oil prices, with rates ranging from 30 cents to 0 cents per barrel. The tax credit extension now applies until 2014, with amendments to the income tax credit table for various calendar years. The VEETC rate is adjusted quarterly based on crude oil prices, with rates ranging from 30 cents to 0 cents per barrel. The tax credit extension now applies until 2014, with amendments to the income tax credit table for various calendar years, including changes such as inserting "Calendar years" before 2009, replacing "2011" with "the last calendar quarter beginning before July 1, 2011", and adding additional information at the end. The tax credit extension now applies until 2015, with amendments to the income tax credit table for various calendar years. The 1st and 2nd applicable rates are determined according to a specific table. The tax credit extension now applies until 2015, with amendments to the income tax credit table for various calendar years. The applicable rates for the calendar quarter are determined based on the average price of crude oil. The rates range from 30 cents to 4.44 cents per barrel, depending on the price range. The tax credit extension applies until 2015 with amendments to the income tax credit table. Rates range from 30 cents to 4.44 cents per barrel based on the average price of crude oil. More than $80 but not more than $90/barrel: 6 cents. More than $90/barrel: 0 cents. The tax credit extension for crude oil prices is amended until 2015. Rates are adjusted based on the average price of oil, with reductions for each calendar year after 2011. The tax credit extension for crude oil prices is amended until 2015, with rates adjusted based on the average price of oil. Section 6426(b)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by removing subparagraph (C) and the changes apply after June 30, 2011. Extension and modification of alternative fuel vehicle refueling property credit. Extension and modification of alternative fuel vehicle refueling property credit. Subsection (g) of section 30C of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to require properties to be placed in service after December 31, 2016, or after the certification of 53,000 qualified alternative fuel refueling properties. Certain ethanol blends are eligible for the credit if they consist of at least 85% natural gas, compressed natural gas, liquefied natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas, or hydrogen. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows for a credit for dual-use refueling property, where 100 percent of the cost is covered. This applies to fuels consisting of ethanol and gasoline, with ethanol making up between 15 to 85 percent of the volume. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows for a credit for dual-use refueling property, where 100 percent of the cost is covered if the property will be used in more than a de minimis capacity for the specified purposes. If the property ceases to be used as required within 5 years, the cost will be subject to recapture. The term 'dual-use refueling property' refers to property that serves as qualified alternative fuel vehicle refueling property and is used to store or dispense fuels not described in subsection (c)(2), or to store fuels described in subsection (c)(2) for purposes other than fueling a motor vehicle. These amendments apply to property placed in service after June 30, 2011. Extension of cellulosic biofuel producer credit through 2014 and special depreciation allowance for cellulosic biofuel plant property extended to January 1, 2015. Algae now considered a qualified feedstock for the cellulosic biofuel producer credit. Algae is now a qualified feedstock for the cellulosic biofuel producer credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Qualified feedstock includes lignocellulosic or hemicellulosic matter available on a renewable basis and cultivated algae or cyanobacteria. Algae, cyanobacteria, or lemna are considered qualified feedstock for the cellulosic biofuel producer credit. Fuel derived from these feedstocks and sold for refining into compliant fuel is subject to special rules, including treatment as meeting requirements in the hands of the taxpayer. Algae, cyanobacteria, or lemna are qualified feedstock for biofuel plant property. The amendment allows for the production of second-generation biofuel instead of cellulosic biofuel. Fuel derived from these feedstocks is subject to special rules for compliance. The amendment allows for the production of second-generation biofuel instead of cellulosic biofuel. Amendments include changes in terminology and conforming amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment replaces references to cellulosic biofuel with "second generation biofuel" in various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, with an effective date for fuels sold or used after the enactment of the Act. The amendments made by subsection (c) apply to property placed in service after the enactment of this Act. The budgetary effects of this Act will not be included on any PAYGO scorecard.
